sentences: Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology
HST.071: Human Reproductive Biology
Course Director: Professor Henry Klapholz
HST 071
[H1] IN SUMMARY.
[H1] FIBROIDS.
[LIST_ITEM] Smooth muscle tumors of the uterus, very common;
[LIST_ITEM] Occur in more than one third of women over the age of 35
[LIST_ITEM] Complaints include discharge, bleeding from the vagina, pain, pressure
[LIST_ITEM] Circumscribed - but not truly encapsulated
[LIST_ITEM] Tumor can be readily "shelled out." - is glistening gray
[LIST_ITEM] Composed of interdigitating bundles of smooth muscle.
[LIST_ITEM] Incidence in black women three times greater than in white women.
[LIST_ITEM] Strong hormonal relationship
[H1] LOCATION.
[LIST_ITEM] Intramural, subserosal, and submucosal
[LIST_ITEM] Subserosal and submucosal leiomyomas may become pedunculated
[LIST_ITEM] Submucosal leiomyomas most important - bleeding symptoms may occur
[LIST_ITEM] May occur in the cervix and broad ligaments as well
[LIST_ITEM] Few mitoses are present
[LIST_ITEM] Their spindle shape is readily apparent.
[LIST_ITEM] When the cells are cut across the nuclei appear round
[LIST_ITEM] Frequently undergo degeneration. - hyaline and cystic
[LIST_ITEM] Presence of large amounts of connective tissue - known as fibromyomas or "fibroids"
[LIST_ITEM] Bleeding symptoms caused in part by thinning of the overlying endometrium
[LIST_ITEM] Vessels are not capable of retracting in the usual manner
[LIST_ITEM] No basal zone from which the overlying thin layer of endometrium can regenerate
[LIST_ITEM] Submucous, pedunculated leiomyomas may prolapse
[LIST_ITEM] Necrosis in intramural leiomyomas - Only one artery supplies the leiomyoma
[LIST_ITEM] May calcify or undergo "red" degeneration
[H1] ATYPICALITY.
[LIST_ITEM] Atypicalities occur in leiomyomas - may be confused with leiomyosarcomas
[LIST_ITEM] Mitotic rate is characteristically less than 5 per 10 high-power fields
[LIST_ITEM] Intravascular leiomyoma - rare tumor - nodular masses of histologically benign smooth muscle growing within veins
[H1] INCIDENCE & ETIOLOGY.
[LIST_ITEM] Most common solid pelvic tumors in women
[LIST_ITEM] Clinically apparent in 20% to 25% of women during the reproductive years
[LIST_ITEM] Pathologic inspection of the uterus - present in more than 80%
[LIST_ITEM] Leiomyomas are clonal in origin
[LIST_ITEM] Classic paradigm â€“ caused by and stimulated to grow by
[LIST_ITEM] Estrogen
[LIST_ITEM] Progesterone
It is now clear that the following are responsible for fibroid growth
[LIST_ITEM] Transforming growth factor-s
[LIST_ITEM] Basic fibroblast growth factor
[LIST_ITEM] Somatic mutations of genes such as HMGI-C
Fibroids are characterized by their location in the uterus
[LIST_ITEM] Subserosal leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Intramural leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Submucous leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Few leiomyomas are actually of a single "pure" type
[LIST_ITEM] Most leiomyomas are hybrids that span more than one anatomic location
[LIST_ITEM] Increased incidence of leiomyomas in women of color
[LIST_ITEM] Risk is increased in women with greater body mass index
[LIST_ITEM] Decreased in women who smoke or who have given birth
IN SUMMARY FIBROIDS HST 071
[LIST_ITEM] Good epidemiological evidence to suggest that use of oral contraceptive
[LIST_ITEM] Birth control pills decreases the risk for leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] 20% and 50% of women with leiomyomas have tumor-related symptoms
[LIST_ITEM] Fibroids often cause
[LIST_ITEM] Abnormal uterine bleeding
[LIST_ITEM] Prolonged menstrual flow (menorrhagia)
[LIST_ITEM] Submucous leiomyomas appear to be particularly prone
[LIST_ITEM] Pelvic pressure.
[LIST_ITEM] Increase in uterine size
[LIST_ITEM] Pressure of particular myomas on adjacent structures
[LIST_ITEM] Colon - constipation
[LIST_ITEM] Bladder - urinary frequency.
[LIST_ITEM] Ureters - hydronephrosis
[LIST_ITEM] Recurrent miscarriage
[LIST_ITEM] Infertility
[LIST_ITEM] Premature labor
[LIST_ITEM] Fetal malpresentation
[LIST_ITEM] Complications of labor
[H1] DIAGNOSIS.
[LIST_ITEM] Easily determined by bimanual examination
[LIST_ITEM] Uterus is enlarged
[LIST_ITEM] Mobile
[LIST_ITEM] Irregular
[LIST_ITEM] Palpated abdominally above the symphysis
[LIST_ITEM] Ultrasonography most common method for diagnosis
[LIST_ITEM] Submucous fibroid can be missed on traditional ultrasonography
[LIST_ITEM] Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
[LIST_ITEM] Electron spin characteristics can often distinguish
[LIST_ITEM] Leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Adenomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Leiomyosarcomas
[LIST_ITEM] Primary therapy for patients with large or symptomatic leiomyomas is surgery
[LIST_ITEM] Hysterectomy is the most often
[LIST_ITEM] United States: more than 175,000 hysterectomies are performed yearly for leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Diagnosis of leiomyoma the most common indication for this procedure
[LIST_ITEM] Hysterectomy, the only true "cure" for leiomyoma, is a surgical option when women are no longer interested in future pregnancies
[LIST_ITEM] Subtraction angiography
[LIST_ITEM] Easily visualize the fibroids and also embolize them in order to cause infarction
[LIST_ITEM] May dramatically reduce bleeding as well as size.
[LIST_ITEM] Myomectomy
[LIST_ITEM] 18,000 myomectomies are performed yearly
[LIST_ITEM] Myomectomy diminishes menorrhagia in roughly 80%
[LIST_ITEM] Significant risk for recurrence of leiomyomas
[LIST_ITEM] Ultrasonography evidence of recurrence in 25% to 51% of patients
[LIST_ITEM] 10% require a second major operative procedure
[LIST_ITEM] GnRH agonists (Lupron, Naferelin, Gosserelin)
[LIST_ITEM] Induce a hypo estrogenic pseudo menopausal state
[LIST_ITEM] Fibroids are dependent on estrogen for their development and growth
[LIST_ITEM] Hypo estrogenic state causes shrinkage
[LIST_ITEM] Uterine volume has been shown to decrease 40% to 60% after 3 months
IN SUMMARY FIBROIDS HST 071
[LIST_ITEM] Induces amenorrhea
[LIST_ITEM] increase iron stores and hemoglobin concentrations
[LIST_ITEM] Cessation of GnRH agonist treatment results in rapid re-growth
[LIST_ITEM] GnRH agonist treatment is useful as a pre-surgical treatment
[LIST_ITEM] Not a long-term treatment option
[LIST_ITEM] Androgenic agents
[LIST_ITEM] Danazol
[LIST_ITEM] Gestrinone
[LIST_ITEM] Progestins
[LIST_ITEM] Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Provera)
[LIST_ITEM] Depo medroxyprogesterone acetate (Depo-Provera)
[LIST_ITEM] Norethindrone
[LIST_ITEM] Do not consistently decrease uterine or fibroid volume
[LIST_ITEM] Mechanism of action is thought to be the induction of endometrial atrophy
[LIST_ITEM] Often not successful in controlling significant menorrhagia
[LIST_ITEM] Somatic mutation is the initial event in most tumorigenesis
[LIST_ITEM] Somatic mutations include a variety of chromosomal aberrations
Point mutations or Chromosomal loss or gain.
[LIST_ITEM] Large chromosomal abnormalities such as translocations and deletions often detected with standard cytogenetic karyotypes
[LIST_ITEM] Independent monoclonal origin of individual myomas
[LIST_ITEM] Suggests somatic mutations offer a selective growth advantage to the mutated myocyte
[H2] Variety of chromosomal rearrangements.
[LIST_ITEM] Most common 12q14-15 and 7q22
[LIST_ITEM] Heterogeneity of the cytogenetic abnormalities
[LIST_ITEM] Different somatic mutations may be involved in myoma tumorigenesis
[LIST_ITEM] Unique somatic mutations in individual myomas
[LIST_ITEM] Biologic basis for the differential responsiveness of individual myomas to a variety of growth-promoting agents
[H2] SOME THOUGHTS ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF FIBROIDS.
[LIST_ITEM] Clonal proliferation precedes the development of cytogenetic rearrangements
[LIST_ITEM] Somatic mutations which cannot be detected cytogenetically with the light microscope are the initial events in myoma tumorigenesis.
[LIST_ITEM] Explains the absence of cytogenetic abnormalities in a large proportion of myoma specimens.
[LIST_ITEM] ER alpha and ER beta mRNA expressed in leiomyoma and normal myometrium.
[LIST_ITEM] Expression of ER alpha higher than ER beta in both leiomyoma & myometrium
[LIST_ITEM] ER alpha expression is increased in leiomyoma compared to that the adjacent normal myometrium
[LIST_ITEM] ER beta expression is same or lower in leiomyoma than in the adjacent normal myometrium
[LIST_ITEM] Estrogen considered the major promoter of myoma growth
[LIST_ITEM] The long-term administration of a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist associated with both hypoestrogenemia and a reduction in myoma volume
[LIST_ITEM] Concentration of estradiol significantly higher in myomas than in normal myometrium.
[LIST_ITEM] Lower conversion of estradiol to estrone in myomas than myometrium.
IN SUMMARY FIBROIDS HST 071
[LIST_ITEM] Significantly increased concentration of estrogen receptors in myomas compared with autologous myometrium
[LIST_ITEM] Observations suggest intramyoma hormonal milieu is hyperestrogenic
[LIST_ITEM] No evidence that estrogen directly stimulates myoma growth
[LIST_ITEM] Mitogenic effects of estrogen are likely mediated by other factors and their receptors.
[LIST_ITEM] Several estrogen-regulated genes have been confirmed
[LIST_ITEM] Evidence to suggest that estrogen stimulates
[LIST_ITEM] progesterone receptor
[LIST_ITEM] epidermal growth factor
[LIST_ITEM] insulin-like growth factor-I
[LIST_ITEM] Regulation of myoma extracellular matrix
[LIST_ITEM] Estrogen directly stimulates collagen types I and III m-RNA
[LIST_ITEM] Stimulates expression of gap junction protein connexin-43
[LIST_ITEM] Stimulates local production of the parathyroid hormone related peptide
[LIST_ITEM] Expression of these estrogen-regulated genes appears to be greater in uterine myomas than in the adjacent myometrium.
[LIST_ITEM] Hypersensitivity to estrogen may be important in the pathogenesis of myomas.
[LIST_ITEM] Ultrastructural features of cultured smooth muscle cells from uterine myomas and normal myometrium
[LIST_ITEM] Myoma and myometrial cells in estrogen and progesterone media more active under EM than cells in estrogen only medium.
[LIST_ITEM] Progesterone exposure -> increased number of myofilaments with dense bodies (suggesting that progesterone is involved in myoma differentiation)
[LIST_ITEM] Increased progesterone receptor m-RNA expression
[LIST_ITEM] Increased progesterone receptor protein levels in myoma tissue compared with adjacent myometrium
[H1] FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What constitutes the female reproductive tract?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Discuss the histologic makeup of the uterus.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Where does the ureter lie with respect to the uterus and why is this important?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Describe the histology of the ovary. What cell lines are present?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is a fibroid?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What hormones make fibroids grow?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Discuss the genetics of fibroids?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What are the clinical manifestations of fibroids?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] How may fibroids be treated?
IN SUMMARY FIBROIDS HST 071
